tasks: Create a simple wireframe of a login form using the 8-point grid system to improve navigation, focusing on error states you missed (Reference: https://lawsofux.com/8-point-grid-system).
Write down 3 pain points from your own experience with collaboration and communication in design teams. Use the Jobs-to-be-Done framework to identify user needs (Reference: lawsofux.com).
Design a new navigation menu for your portfolio using the 8-point grid system, focusing on clear typography and concise labels.
Create a low-fidelity wireframe of a checkout flow, incorporating Tesler’s Law (lawsofux.com) to reduce cognitive load. Focus on simplifying the process.
Conduct 1 user interview and document 3 pain points using the Zeigarnik Effect (lawsofux.com).
Redesign your portfolio's navigation menu using a simple, intuitive layout, focusing on clear typography and concise labels.
Create an interactive prototype of a login form using the Aesthetic-Usability Effect (lawsofux.com) to improve user experience. Focus on visual appeal.
Write down 5 principles for effective collaboration and communication in design teams, referencing the Laws of UX (lawsofux.com).
Design a new color palette for your portfolio's navigation menu, focusing on contrast and usability.
Create an advanced interactive prototype of a checkout flow using the Aesthetic-Usability Effect (lawsofux.com) to improve user experience. Focus on visual appeal and usability.
Conduct 2 user interviews and document 5 pain points using the Tesler’s Law (lawsofux.com).
Redesign your portfolio's navigation menu using a complex, intuitive layout, focusing on clear typography and concise labels.

resources.readup: As an Explorer UX designer, you have the unique opportunity to shape the user experience of innovative products and services. To excel in this role, focus on developing a strong foundation in UX fundamentals, UI craft, and collaboration, while continually seeking opportunities for growth and improvement.

resources.title: 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design
resources.description: 7 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design ================================================= Jakob Nielsen ![](https://media.nngroup.com/medi...

topics.name: Understanding Jakob's Law and its Application in UI Design
topics.summary: Jakob's Law states that users read content from left to right, top to bottom. As an Explorer designer, understanding this law is crucial for creating effective UI designs.
practice_points: Create a wireframe of a website with clear navigation and content hierarchy, using Jakob's Law as a guiding principle
Conduct 2 usability testing sessions to validate the effectiveness of Jakob's Law in real-world scenarios
Design 3 different versions of a UI element (e.g. button) that adhere to Jakob's Law and test user preferences

topics.name: Applying Tesler’s Law for Consistent Branding
topics.summary: Tesler’s Law states that users prefer consistent visual elements. As an Explorer designer, applying this law can lead to a more cohesive brand identity.
practice_points: Create a comprehensive style guide with consistent typography, color schemes, and spacing tokens
Design 3 different versions of a logo that adhere to Tesler’s Law for consistency
Conduct 2 user interviews to validate the importance of consistent branding in UX design

topics.name: Using Aesthetic-Usability Effect to Improve UI Design
topics.summary: The Aesthetic-Usability Effect states that users are more likely to engage with visually appealing designs. As an Explorer designer, incorporating this principle can lead to more engaging UX experiences.
practice_points: Design 3 different versions of a UI element (e.g. button) that incorporate the Aesthetic-Usability Effect
Conduct 2 usability testing sessions to validate the effectiveness of the Aesthetic-Usability Effect in real-world scenarios
Create a wireframe of a website with visually appealing design elements that adhere to the Aesthetic-Usability Effect

insights.brief: Score meaning for Explorer, indicating areas where UX principles need improvement.
insights.detailed: The low score in UX Fundamentals suggests that the design may not be following best practices, leading to a poor user experience. This could be due to issues with layout, navigation, or interaction design.
actionable: Conduct a heuristic evaluation of the design to identify usability issues and areas for improvement
Research industry standards and best practices in UX design to update knowledge and skills
Create a style guide to ensure consistency in design elements and principles

insights.brief: Score meaning for Explorer, indicating areas where visual design needs improvement.
insights.detailed: The low score in UI Craft & Visual Design suggests that the design may not be visually appealing or effective in communicating information. This could be due to issues with color scheme, typography, or imagery.
actionable: Create a mood board to identify and refine visual design elements
Research current design trends and styles to update knowledge and skills
Develop a visual design system to ensure consistency across the product

insights.brief: Score meaning for Explorer, indicating areas where user research needs improvement.
insights.detailed: The low score in User Research & Validation suggests that the design may not be meeting user needs or expectations. This could be due to issues with user personas, user journeys, or usability testing.
actionable: Conduct user interviews and surveys to gather feedback and validate assumptions
Create user personas and user journeys to inform design decisions
Plan and conduct usability testing to identify areas for improvement

insights.brief: Score meaning for Explorer, indicating areas where product thinking needs improvement.
insights.detailed: The low score in Product Thinking & Strategy suggests that the design may not be aligned with business goals or user needs. This could be due to issues with product vision, customer segments, or market analysis.
actionable: Develop a product roadmap to align design decisions with business goals
Research target customer segments and create buyer personas
Analyze market trends and competitor products to inform design decisions

insights.brief: Score meaning for Explorer, indicating areas where collaboration and communication need improvement.
insights.detailed: The low score in Collaboration & Communication suggests that the design team may not be effectively communicating with stakeholders or working collaboratively. This could be due to issues with project management, stakeholder engagement, or team dynamics.
actionable: Create a project plan and timeline to ensure clear communication and task assignments
Establish regular check-ins and feedback loops with stakeholders and team members
Develop a design process that incorporates collaboration and iteration
